articles.headline: U.S. Said to Look Into Microsoft Bribery Allegations
articles.snippet: The S.E.C. and Justice Department are investigating accusations involving the company in China, Italy and Romania, a person briefed on the matter said.
articles.abstract: The S.E.C. and Justice Department are investigating accusations involving the company in China, Italy and Romania, a person briefed on the matter said.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Federal authorities are examining Microsoft’s involvement with companies and individuals that are accused of paying bribes to overseas government officials in exchange for business, according to a person briefed on the inquiry.

articles.headline: A Model for Reducing Emissions
articles.snippet: Energy costs and market-driven technological advances have led to a major reduction in greenhouse gas emissions.
articles.abstract: Energy costs and market-driven technological advances have led to a major reduction in greenhouse gas emissions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Who would have thought the United States would one day be a leader in cutting greenhouse gas emissions?

articles.headline: Real Fur, Masquerading as Faux
articles.snippet: In a forehead-slapping development, Neiman Marcus and two other retailers settled federal claims that they had marketed rabbit, raccoon and other real fur as fake fur.
articles.abstract: In a forehead-slapping development, Neiman Marcus and two other retailers settled federal claims that they had marketed rabbit, raccoon and other real fur as fake fur.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Stuart Weitzman ballet flats from Neiman Marcus sported sweet faux fur pom-poms. The Alice and Olivia coat was trimmed with a dark faux fur collar.

articles.headline: JPMorgan Chase Is Reining In Payday Lenders
articles.snippet: Bank customers will be allowed to stop withdrawals for high-interest payday loans and close their accounts sooner.
articles.abstract: Bank customers will be allowed to stop withdrawals for high-interest payday loans and close their accounts sooner.
articles.lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase will make changes to protect consumers who have borrowed money from a rising power on the Internet — payday lenders offering short-term loans with interest rates that can exceed 500 percent.

articles.headline: Sectarian Strains Pit Some Iraqis Against Their Own Leaders
articles.snippet: Rafe al-Essawi, until recently Iraq’s finance minister and one of the highest-ranking Sunni politicians, is now on the run from the Shiite-led government.
articles.abstract: Rafe al-Essawi, until recently Iraq’s finance minister and one of the highest-ranking Sunni politicians, is now on the run from the Shiite-led government.
articles.lead_paragraph: RAMADI, Iraq — As Rafe al-Essawi, the embattled Sunni leader, sped south on a desert highway last week to attend the funeral of a political ally who was assassinated, his cellphone rang with a warning: Up ahead, Iraqi soldiers, backed by two helicopters hovering overhead, planned to arrest him.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango and Michael R. Gordon

articles.headline: In a New Aisle, Energy Drinks Sidestep Some Rules
articles.snippet: The producer of Monster Energy will no longer be required to tell federal regulators about reports potentially linking its products to deaths and injuries.
articles.abstract: The producer of Monster Energy will no longer be required to tell federal regulators about reports potentially linking its products to deaths and injuries.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fans of Monster Energy, the popular high-caffeine energy drink, may not notice the change: its ingredients will be the same and its familiar label bearing a green, clawlike monogram will change only slightly. But the drink’s maker has decided after a decade of selling it as a dietary supplement to market it as a beverage, a switch that will bring significant changes in how it is regulated.

articles.headline: Justices Explore Fine Line on Generic Drug Injuries
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court heard arguments Tuesday on whether a drug maker could be held responsible for severe injuries caused by its generic pain pill.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court heard arguments Tuesday on whether a drug maker could be held responsible for severe injuries caused by its generic pain pill.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In 2010, a New Hampshire jury awarded Karen Bartlett $21 million for the ordeal she endured from taking a generic pain pill for an aching shoulder. It caused two-thirds of her skin to slough off, damaged her lungs and esophagus and rendered her legally blind.

articles.headline: On Gay Unions, a Pragmatist Before He Was a Pope
articles.snippet: By suggesting in 2010 that the church in Argentina support civil unions for gay couples, Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio revealed himself to be a deal maker willing to compromise.
articles.abstract: By suggesting in 2010 that the church in Argentina support civil unions for gay couples, Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio revealed himself to be a deal maker willing to compromise.
articles.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — The very idea was anathema to many of the bishops in the room.
articles.byline: By Simon Romero and Emily Schmall

articles.headline: G.O.P. Opposition to Immigration Law Is Falling Away
articles.snippet: A scramble by leading Republican lawmakers to halt a loss of support among Hispanic voters is providing strong momentum for an immigration overhaul.
articles.abstract: A scramble by leading Republican lawmakers to halt a loss of support among Hispanic voters is providing strong momentum for an immigration overhaul.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republican opposition to legalizing the status of millions of illegal immigrants is crumbling in the nation’s capital as leading lawmakers in the party scramble to halt eroding support among Hispanic voters — a shift that is providing strong momentum for an overhaul of immigration laws.
articles.byline: By Ashley Parker and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: As Bailout Deadline Approaches, Cyprus Scrambles to Find Funds
articles.snippet: One proposal would nationalize pension funds from state-run companies and hold an emergency bond sale in an effort to raise €5.8 billion.
articles.abstract: One proposal would nationalize pension funds from state-run companies and hold an emergency bond sale in an effort to raise €5.8 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: NICOSIA, Cyprus — Scrambling to placate international lenders, Cyprus late Wednesday proposed to nationalize pension funds from state-run companies and conduct an emergency bond sale to help raise the €5.8 billion the indebted country needs to secure a bailout.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman and David M. Herszenhorn

articles.headline: Chinese Solar Panel Giant Is Tainted by Bankruptcy
articles.snippet: A solar panel maker, Wuxi Suntech, declared bankruptcy in a remarkable reversal for part of a huge Chinese government effort to dominate renewable energy industries.
articles.abstract: A solar panel maker, Wuxi Suntech, declared bankruptcy in a remarkable reversal for part of a huge Chinese government effort to dominate renewable energy industries.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — It was the Icarus of the solar power industry. And, on Wednesday, it fell to earth.

articles.headline: Study of Men’s Falling Income Cites Single Parents
articles.snippet: Boys raised in single-parent households, particularly those headed by women, appeared to fare poorly.
articles.abstract: Boys raised in single-parent households, particularly those headed by women, appeared to fare poorly.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The decline of two-parent households may be a significant reason for the divergent fortunes of male workers, whose earnings generally declined in recent decades, and female workers, whose earnings generally increased, a prominent labor economist argues in a new survey of existing research.
